# Chapter 16 (Enhanced Pacing & Flow)

Deadpool prowled the scorched arcade floor, mask scrunched in mock concern. “Pop quiz: If I mash this button,” he declared, hovering over a battered control panel, “do we save the multiverse, or end up collectible bobbleheads with zero resale value?”

Morty, elbow-deep in a tangled nest of wires, didn’t look up. “Don’t *even* joke about that, man!” He furiously duct-taped a half-melted joystick. “The void behind those eyes... I still see it when I close mine.”

Rick commandeered the dented prize counter, feet tangled in old Game Boy cords, hands buried in obsolete tech. “Push the button, Wade,” he grunted flatly. “Worst case, we get recast for a ‘dark and edgy’ reboot. No singing, no dancing, and everything’s beige.”

Deadpool twirled his katana, grinning. “That’s the spirit! Chaos, here we come.” And—because nobody ever stopped him, even when they really, really should have—he smacked the oversized, flashing button.

The arcade spasmed. Fractals of neon meta-energy ripped the air. Walls shivered into a sitcom living room—laugh track and all—then a rain-slick noir alley, then a flaring pixel dungeon. Morty squeaked in panic as a couch materialized beneath him, launching him skyward.

“Ahh! My spleen can’t take this much irony—!” Morty crash-landed as the room flickered back to its battered, patchwork reality.

Rick just shook his head, still rooting for scavenged parts. “Congrats. We broke physics *and* comedy timing.” As if on cue, a tinned audience guffawed overhead.

Deadpool dusted off his gloves. “If we implode, I want my entry fee back. If we survive, I call sitcom spinoff rights. Working title: ‘Law & Order: Meta Victims Unit.’”

As he spoke, a jagged rift split the arcade floor. Electric-violet light pulsed, spewing fractured comic captions. The three locked eyes—daredevil, scientist, anxious everyteen. No time for debate: jump or get pixelated.

Morty shoved Deadpool’s hand away from a now-manic button. “Have you ever *not* triggered a cataclysm by poking the shiny thing?”

Deadpool gasped, wounded. “Hey! I have *some* impulse control. I just let the plot repress it.”

Rick, wrist-deep in his portal gun, didn’t look up. “If you clowns keep poking things, we’ll wind up as cheaply animated webisodes. Help, Morty: quantum disinhibitor—blue wires, don’t touch the red.”

Morty dove into Rick’s ragged backpack, past a radioactive Slinky and what looked way too much like a Mr. Meeseeks box. “Is—this it? It’s humming. That’s bad, right?”

“Safer than trusting Wade.” Rick’s hands worked feverishly, a wild glint in his eyes. “If everything goes sideways, aim for the blinking part and run.”

The arcade’s lights spasmed, strobing white and venom-green. Above the skee-ball lanes, a swirling vortex tore open, howling and flinging speech bubbles and cartoon monkey arms into the chaos. The meta-rift yawned wider, growing impossible teeth.

Morty stared, skin gone paper-pale. “Rick, what's *happening*?”

Rick’s voice was tight, grave. “Narrative rift. Our ‘Big Bad’ just hit fast-forward on continuity. Wade—no improv. We’re on defense.”

Deadpool whipped both katanas up, slicing a drifting balloon that flipped between “KABOOM!” and “OOPSIE!” He struck a pose. “They can’t even settle on a catchphrase. Lazy writing 101.”

He planted himself in front of the breach, blades ready. “Fourth-wall hazard pay better come with dental.”

A monstrous cartoon hand ripped at the thinning air, shredding what passed for reality.

Morty hugged himself, eyeing the glowing glyphs slithering up the walls. “Rule of thumb: glowing runes always mean doom. Last week you leveled the garage with three.”

Deadpool eyed the glyphs. “Mort, glowing runes *are* my vibe. That, and bad ideas involving C-4.”

Rick snapped, voice bright with urgency. “Either shut up or hand me the doohickey! Nothing marked ‘fatal,’ ‘meta,’ or ‘do not push!’”

But the glyphs already surged, warping the arcade into jagged, wavering panels. Shadows bucked and twisted. Deadpool tensed, blades spinning. “Last time I saw those colors, I woke up handcuffed on a Skrull honeymoon cruise. Would not recommend.”

Then—a seismic tear shuddered through the air. A thunderous, disembodied voice boomed: “**You dare tamper with the Meta-Nexus? Prepare for disconnection!**” The villain’s laughter tumbled down, trailing glitched pixels in its wake.

Rick fumbled the quantum disinhibitor, sweat at his brow. “Meta-police. Fan-freakin’-tastic. Cover me. And—if you blow up, do it off-camera.”

The arcade convulsed, ceiling raining comic debris. Deadpool faced the incoming breach, grinning beneath his mask, utterly fearless. “Cheer up, Morty. ‘Unraveling reality’ beats double-period algebra.”

As Rick hunched over his tech, and Morty gaped, Deadpool stepped into the pulse and mayhem—defiant, blades ready, more himself than ever.

A brittle silence descended, broken only by static from a dead laugh track. Reality groaned. And with every pulsing second, survival odds—sanity included—plummeted.
